 JUDGMENT (Per: Deshmukh, J.) . 

 1. This bunch of writ petitions arises out of judgment and order dated 22.11.2002 

 
 passed by the learned Maharashtra Administrative Tribunal [hereinafter referred to as 
 
 "the Tribunal"] in Original Applications No. 254 and 256 of 2000, and subsequent orders 

 passed in Contempt Petition No 89 of 2003 and other proceedings. [Petitioners herein 
 
 are referred to as 'Petitioners' and original applicants before MAT as 'The applicants" and 

 the Governments Authorities either as 'Authorities' or 'Respondents no. 1 to 3' for 

 convenience]
 

 2. Original Application No. 254 of 2000 had been filed on 07-04-2000 by four 
 

 applicants, who are direct recruits to the Maharashtra Development Service ("MDS") 

 Class I cadre, against Respondents No. 1 to 3 - the government authorities and 

 Respondents No. 4 to 24 in said original application, who are the promotees to MDS 

 Class-I cadre, praying for placement of the applicants in seniority list of said cadre above 

 said Respondents No. 2 to 24 and for consequential benefits. 

 3. On 10-04-2000, applicants in Original Application No. 254 of 2000 had filed 

 Original Application No.256 of 2000 arraigning only aforesaid Respondents No. 1 to 3- 

 the govt. authorities, seeking directions to work out and declare number of posts 

 earmarked for direct recruits from 01-04-1982 and also to workout number of promotee 

 ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2013 18:19:15 :::

 15 JTWP-2466.05(2).doc

 candidates considering their promotions in excess of the recruitment/quota rules to be 

 
 fortuitous in MDS Class-I cadre and to fill up the created posts of Additional Chief 

 Executive Officers in Zilla Parishad in accordance with quota rule. 

 4. According to the applicants, MDS cadre has been an altogether new cadre formed in 

 1973, consisting of Class-I and Class-II posts pursuant to Maharashtra Development 

 
 [Constitution, Classification and Recruitment] Rules, 1973 [hereinafter referred to as 

 'MDS Rules, 1973'] and the posts in said cadre were meant to be filled in by promotion as 

 well as by nomination with prescription that appointments of direct recruits [nomination] 

 
 shall be in the range of 35 to 50 per cent and the rest by promotion [departmental 
 
 candidates]. The MDS Rules, 1973, have been framed in exercise of powers conferred 

 upon the State of Maharashtra under proviso to 
Article 309
 of the Constitution of India. 

 According to them, in order to achieve proportion of 35 per cent of direct recruits till 

 1.4.1982 and 50 percent thereafter, and to maintain the proportion under the rules, the 

 State Government ought to take proper steps and timely action.

 5. The applicants have submitted that sub-rule (1) of Rule 5 of the MDS Rules, 

 1973, requires that appointment by nomination shall be through the Commission in 

 accordance with the rules relating to recruitment to the posts of Deputy Collectors and 

 that proviso thereunder requires the same to be effective from 1.4.1979 or thereafter in 

 such a phased manner as would ensure that the total number of officers directly recruited 

 in MDS Class-I cadre shall not at any time after 1.4.1982, be less than 35 per cent and 

 more than 50 per cent of the total number of permanent posts in that cadre. 

 6. The applicants have alleged that respondent authorities did not take action on 

 their representation in accordance with rules. According to them, direct recruitment 

 was sought only in 1987 though it was expected immediately on enforcement of the 

 ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2013 18:19:16 :::

 16 JTWP-2466.05(2).doc

 rules and alleged that initiation had been only in 1985. Government had been loath to 

 
 take action which has given rise to promotion of in-service candidates from Class-II 

 cadre. According to the applicants, all promotions of in-service candidates which are in 

 
 excess of rules are to be regarded as fortuitous. The applicants purport to go back to 

 August, 1973 and seek review of the situation and removal of disparity created due to 

 
 alleged non observance of quota rule. According to them, there had been no situational 

 constraints justifying listless approach of concerned authorities. Applicants cannot be 

 made to suffer on account of negligence and absence of timely action by the authorities. 

 According to the applicants, no explanation in this respect should be heard from the 

 authorities and the authorities are required to be directed to work out the number posts 
 
 which were and have been earmarked for direct recruitment and to work out their 
 
 backlog and take suitable steps to remove disparity and to give deemed date to the direct 

 recruits which they would have got in regular course. The applicants contend that 

 seniority of the promotee candidates from MDS Class-II cadre cannot be reckoned from 
 

 the date of their actual promotion to MDS Class-I cadre having regard to proportion of 

 respective categories in MDS Class-I cadre to be maintained according to the rules, 
 

 contending that promotions are not according to the rules. The applicants had 

 requested Respondent No. 1 to look into the matter and make suitable alterations to the 

 seniority list by properly following quota rule, to remove injustice caused to them. The 

 applicants purport to place reliance on a few judicial pronouncements. The applicants 

 contend that if suitable changes are not made to the seniority list, MDS Rules, 1973, 

 would lose their sanctity. Apprehending a situation that the rules may not be followed in 

 view of a news published about the Minister having declared that the creation of 

 Additional Chief Executive Officers' posts in Zilla Parishad in the State is for providing a 

 promotional avenue and thus justifying original applications praying for reliefs referred 

 ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2013 18:19:16 :::

 17 JTWP-2466.05(2).doc

 to hereinabove.

 7. The applicants have claimed that they are graduates and post graduates in various 

 
 disciplines and are working in MDS Class-l cadre posts, and that MDS Class-I cadre 

 comprises Deputy Chief Executive Officers of Zilla Parishad and its equivalent posts viz. 

 Block Development Officers Class-I, Project Officers Class-I of various units under the 

 
 Zilla Parishad.

 8. Maharashtra Public Service Commission [hereinafter referred to as "MPSC" or 

 
 "Commission" ] examination of the applicants had been held in March, 1988 and the final 
 
 outcome had been declared on 11.7.1988. According to applicants such declaration is a 

 recommendation to appoint them in MDS cadre of the Deputy Chief Executive Officer 
 
 Class-I and Block Development Officer Class-I. The applicants refer to a circular dated 

 3.12.1971 issued by the General Administration Department of Maharashtra Government 

 instructing appointments of the candidates selected and recommended by MPSC or by 
 

 Regional Selection Board within a period of one month by completing requisite 
 

 formalities and further refer to circular dated 4.4.1991 instructing expeditious 

 appointments of MPSC recommended candidates and to speed up the process, wherever, 

 delays in such appointments have been brought to notice by the Members of Legislative 

 Assembly/Council.

 9. The applicants make a grievance that though MPSC had recommended their 

 candidature to the government for appointment on 11.7.1988 and though they were 

 directed to undergo medical examination under communication dated 8.9.1988, yet the 

 orders were issued to them only on 1.7.1989 i.e. almost after about twelve months. 

 ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2013 18:19:16 :::

 18 JTWP-2466.05(2).doc

 10. The applicants' grievance is also that on 29.6.1989 i.e. just two days before their 

 
 orders of appointment dated 1.7.1989, orders of promotion of in-service candidates from 

 MDS Class-II cadre had been issued by which en-bloc ten persons were promoted. It has 

 
 been alleged that intervening 23 promotions from the date of recommendation of the 

 applicants to the date of their actual appointments had been calculated at giving 

 
 precedence to the promotee candidates over the direct recruits. The promotee candidates 

 who retired before the applications were filed, have been excluded from being arrayed as 

 respondents. The applicants purport to allege that long distance in the appointments 

 
 had been influenced by the promotee candidates. The applicants contend that not only 

 the ten candidates referred to above, but respondents No. 4 to 26 have been promoted 
 
 keeping the issue of appointment of the applicants in abeyance. 

 11. The applicants allege that even the constitution of the Departmental Promotion 

 Committee [hereinafter referred to as the "DPC"] had been subsequent to the date on 

 which applicants' names were recommended by MPSC and thus claim that the 
 

 departmental candidates' selection is subsequent in point of time. The applicants have 
 

 also contended that since the government had requisitioned direct recruits to the MPSC 

 in 1987 pursuant to which their selection had been made, it has to be presumed that 

 there were vacancies of direct recruits in MDS Class-I cadre. The applicants purported to 

 urge the Tribunal to consider the aspect as to why the State Government had remained 

 inactive and as to how it has issued orders of appointment of the applicants immediately 

 after the date of promotion of the in-service candidates. Sum and substance is to allege 

 that the deferred issuance of appointment orders to them has been malafide, with a view 

 to favour the promotee candidates. The applicants contend that regularization of 

 promotion of the departmental candidates had not taken place. Placing the departmental 

 promotee candidates over the direct recruits in the seniority list dated 7.6.1996 is grossly 

 ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2013 18:19:16 :::

 19 JTWP-2466.05(2).doc

 improper and that though they sought redressal of their grievance regarding said 

 
 seniority list under a representation dated 15.1.1999, yet there has been no response. 

 12. The respondents-applicants claimed that there was no avenue available to those 

 working in MDS Class I cadre till 1999. It is only in 1999 the government has given 

 them opportunity of getting Selection Grade in MDS cadre and also promotional avenue 

 
 in the form of Additional Chief Executive Officer and thus they have contended that 

 creation of the cadre of Additional Chief Executive Officer shall have to be deemed to be 

 a reckoning point for the applicants to ventilate their grievance about seniority as taking 

 
 up such issue to judicial forum at other point of time would have generally been an 
 
 academic exercise. The applicants this way justify their approach to the Tribunal 

 questioning the seniority list dated 7.6.1996 and claimed that soon after declaration of 
 
 policy of the State to provide opportunity of advancement to the candidates in MDS 

 Class-I, they have agitated for correction in the seniority list and have requested the 

 Tribunal to appreciate and consider their case favourably. The applicants allege that the 
 

 promotee candidates were in excess of their quota. 

 13. Respondent No. 1 in its affidavit in reply dated 12.1.2001 has denied allegations 

 of the applicants and has asserted that quota of direct recruits and promotees was and 

 has been maintained according to the MDS rules. The objections against interim 

 seniority list received, were considered properly and thereafter seniority list was 

 finalized. It has been submitted that interim seniority list had been prepared on 

 2.8.1995 and after inviting and considering objections to the same, on 7.6.1996, 

 seniority list has been finalized. It has been submitted that MDS Rules, 1973 have been 

 made effective from July, 1981 and the MPSC had been requisitioned in 1984. 

 Examination was held in 1985 and 14 and 16 candidates were appointed in 1986 and 

 ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2013 18:19:16 :::

 20 JTWP-2466.05(2).doc

 1987 respectively through the Commission and as such, the respondent-authorities had 

 
 fulfilled the quota of direct recruits. It has been specifically denied that the departmental 

 candidates had been promoted against the nomination quota. The Rural Development 

 
 Department had prepared seniority list according to the relevant rules and ratio of direct 

 recruits and promotees had been maintained in accordance with the rules. It has been 

 
 denied that the seniority list of the candidates of MDS Group-A requires any alteration. 

 In support of said contention, reliance has been placed by Respondent No. 1 on various 

 documents annexed to the reply, including MDS Rules, 1973 and amendments thereto 

 
 from time to time.

 14. 
 
 The applicants had filed rejoinder on 13.2.2001 to the affidavit in reply 

 submitted by Respondent No.1 and expressed their inability to give definitive figures of 
 
 various posts in MDS Class-I cadre and tried to reason that out on various counts. It has 

 been contended that since Class-I posts were en-bloc converted into Class-II and some of 

 the Class-II posts had been up-graded as Class-I posts, referring to that about 200 posts 
 

 of Child Development Programme Officer (CDPO) which were earlier Class I had been 
 

 converted into Class II. According to them, certain number of posts had been increased 

 and altogether new posts were created like Assistant Commissioner, Additional Chief 

 Officer of Zilla Parishad and also submitted that in the absence of exact figures, effective 

 adjudication of the issue would be difficult. It is further submitted that strength of the 

 MDS Class-I cadre is about 397 or thereabout throughout the State. Till rejoinder, the 

 posts of Assistant Commissioner from said cadre had been increased from 6 to 18 and 

 the posts of Block Development Officer Class-I which were 32 had been increased to 202 

 and about 150 posts of CDPOs had been abolished by shifting them as Block 

 Development Officer Class-II with conversion of CDPOs to MDS Class II from Class I 

 cadre. According to the applicants, there were only 93 direct recruits among 397 posts 

 ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2013 18:19:16 :::

 21 JTWP-2466.05(2).doc

 which is far too below the requirement of 50 per cent under the quota rule since 

 
 1.4.1982 and claimed a backlog of 105 posts of direct recruits. The applicants purport 

 to dispute the date of application of rules as of 1979. The applicants have also contended 

 
 that the objection to seniority list is a different issue altogether and does not have nexus 

 to the controversy involved in Original Application No. 256 of 2000 and thus questioned 

 
 importance being given to the issue of not availing an opportunity to object to the 

 seniority list. The applicants further went on to submit that though the issues are inter-

 mixed, those are, in fact, independent of each other. It has been submitted that 

 
 maintenance of quota can be considered independently from seniority. It has been 

 contended that promotions in favour of the concerned respondents-departmental 
 
 candidates had been temporary and by way of stop gap arrangement and relying upon 
 
 judicial pronouncements of the Apex Court and the Tribunal further contended that 

 promotions of the departmental candidates are fortuitous and apprehended that their 

 long tenure would be legitimized. The applicants purport to claim that in their objections 
 

 to the seniority list they had relied on Sanjay Thakre's case decided by the Tribunal and 

 referred to that challenge to said decision of the Tribunal before the Apex Court had 
 

 been unsuccessful. 

 15. An additional affidavit has been filed by Respondents No. 1 to 3 on 7.3.2001 to 

 the rejoinder of the applicants, objecting to Original Application No. 256 of 2000 on 

 various grounds, inter alia, that the same is barred by limitation, is misconceived, is not 

 tenable, is on fancied cause of action, is stale, fixation of seniority and change in postings 

 cannot be allowed after more than 12 years, etc. It has been contended that the original 

 application has been filed far beyond expiry of period of one year from accrual of cause of 

 action as per 
Section 21
 of the Administrative Tribunals Act, 1985 and that too has been 

 filed without any application for condonation of delay. It has further been submitted 

 ::: Downloaded on - 09/06/2013 18:19:16 :::

 22 JTWP-2466.05(2).doc

 that there is no compliance of requirement under 
section 20
 of said Act, namely, making

 108. When the field is governed and occupied by specific rules, as in present case like 

 MDS Rules 1973 which have been clear and unambiguous, there had been no room to 

 place an interpretation on the same than its plain words. The Tribunal as such has erred 

 
 in going beyond the spirit and letter of the proviso to clause (a) of sub rule (1) of Rule 5.

 109. Though rival arguments have been advanced before us by petitioners so also by 

 the respondents that the original application was beyond limitation and per contra that it 
 
 is within limitation, we do not find it necessary to go into that aspect of the matter. The 

 learned Tribunal after hearing the parties has decided the matter on merits. We have 

 also considered the matter on merits and, as such, it would not be appropriate at this 
 

 stage to go into that issue.

 110. In our considered view, therefore, the Tribunal has wholly misconceived the 

 scope of the matter before it had been in error all over. The impugned order cannot be 

 justified with the aid of material on record. The Tribunal, thus, has erred in issuing 

 impugned directions to prepare fresh seniority list. Looking at the matter in any way, 

 the impugned order passed by the Tribunal dated 22-11-2002 and the one dated 

 28-04-2004 are wholly unsustainable and deserve to be quashed and set aside and as its 

 incident, the impugned seniority list would not be able to stand.

JUDGMENT (Per: Deshmukh, J.) .
1. This bunch of writ petitions arises out of judgment and order dated 22.11.2002

passed by the learned Maharashtra Administrative Tribunal [hereinafter referred to as 
 
 "the Tribunal"] in Original Applications No. 254 and 256 of 2000, and subsequent orders

passed in Contempt Petition No 89 of 2003 and other proceedings. [Petitioners herein 
 
 are referred to as 'Petitioners' and original applicants before MAT as 'The applicants" and
the Governments Authorities either as 'Authorities' or 'Respondents no. 1 to 3' for
convenience]
2. Original Application No. 254 of 2000 had been filed on 07-04-2000 by four
applicants, who are direct recruits to the Maharashtra Development Service ("MDS")
Class I cadre, against Respondents No. 1 to 3 - the government authorities and
Respondents No. 4 to 24 in said original application, who are the promotees to MDS
Class-I cadre, praying for placement of the applicants in seniority list of said cadre above
said Respondents No. 2 to 24 and for consequential benefits.
3. On 10-04-2000, applicants in Original Application No. 254 of 2000 had filed
Original Application No.256 of 2000 arraigning only aforesaid Respondents No. 1 to 3-
the govt. authorities, seeking directions to work out and declare number of posts
earmarked for direct recruits from 01-04-1982 and also to workout number of promotee
candidates considering their promotions in excess of the recruitment/quota rules to be
fortuitous in MDS Class-I cadre and to fill up the created posts of Additional Chief
Executive Officers in Zilla Parishad in accordance with quota rule.
4. According to the applicants, MDS cadre has been an altogether new cadre formed in
1973, consisting of Class-I and Class-II posts pursuant to Maharashtra Development
[Constitution, Classification and Recruitment] Rules, 1973 [hereinafter referred to as
'MDS Rules, 1973'] and the posts in said cadre were meant to be filled in by promotion as
well as by nomination with prescription that appointments of direct recruits [nomination]

shall be in the range of 35 to 50 per cent and the rest by promotion [departmental 
 
 candidates]. The MDS Rules, 1973, have been framed in exercise of powers conferred

upon the State of Maharashtra under proviso to 
Article 309
 of the Constitution of India.
According to them, in order to achieve proportion of 35 per cent of direct recruits till
1.4.1982 and 50 percent thereafter, and to maintain the proportion under the rules, the
State Government ought to take proper steps and timely action.
5. The applicants have submitted that sub-rule (1) of Rule 5 of the MDS Rules,
1973, requires that appointment by nomination shall be through the Commission in
accordance with the rules relating to recruitment to the posts of Deputy Collectors and
that proviso thereunder requires the same to be effective from 1.4.1979 or thereafter in
such a phased manner as would ensure that the total number of officers directly recruited
in MDS Class-I cadre shall not at any time after 1.4.1982, be less than 35 per cent and
more than 50 per cent of the total number of permanent posts in that cadre.
6. The applicants have alleged that respondent authorities did not take action on
their representation in accordance with rules. According to them, direct recruitment
was sought only in 1987 though it was expected immediately on enforcement of the
rules and alleged that initiation had been only in 1985. Government had been loath to
take action which has given rise to promotion of in-service candidates from Class-II
cadre. According to the applicants, all promotions of in-service candidates which are in
excess of rules are to be regarded as fortuitous. The applicants purport to go back to
August, 1973 and seek review of the situation and removal of disparity created due to
alleged non observance of quota rule. According to them, there had been no situational
constraints justifying listless approach of concerned authorities. Applicants cannot be
made to suffer on account of negligence and absence of timely action by the authorities.
According to the applicants, no explanation in this respect should be heard from the

authorities and the authorities are required to be directed to work out the number posts 
 
 which were and have been earmarked for direct recruitment and to work out their 
 
 backlog and take suitable steps to remove disparity and to give deemed date to the direct
recruits which they would have got in regular course. The applicants contend that
seniority of the promotee candidates from MDS Class-II cadre cannot be reckoned from
the date of their actual promotion to MDS Class-I cadre having regard to proportion of
respective categories in MDS Class-I cadre to be maintained according to the rules,
contending that promotions are not according to the rules. The applicants had
requested Respondent No. 1 to look into the matter and make suitable alterations to the
seniority list by properly following quota rule, to remove injustice caused to them. The
applicants purport to place reliance on a few judicial pronouncements. The applicants
contend that if suitable changes are not made to the seniority list, MDS Rules, 1973,
would lose their sanctity. Apprehending a situation that the rules may not be followed in
view of a news published about the Minister having declared that the creation of
Additional Chief Executive Officers' posts in Zilla Parishad in the State is for providing a
promotional avenue and thus justifying original applications praying for reliefs referred
to hereinabove.
7. The applicants have claimed that they are graduates and post graduates in various
disciplines and are working in MDS Class-l cadre posts, and that MDS Class-I cadre
comprises Deputy Chief Executive Officers of Zilla Parishad and its equivalent posts viz.
Block Development Officers Class-I, Project Officers Class-I of various units under the
Zilla Parishad.
8. Maharashtra Public Service Commission [hereinafter referred to as "MPSC" or

"Commission" ] examination of the applicants had been held in March, 1988 and the final 
 
 outcome had been declared on 11.7.1988. According to applicants such declaration is a

recommendation to appoint them in MDS cadre of the Deputy Chief Executive Officer 
 
 Class-I and Block Development Officer Class-I. The applicants refer to a circular dated
3.12.1971 issued by the General Administration Department of Maharashtra Government
instructing appointments of the candidates selected and recommended by MPSC or by
Regional Selection Board within a period of one month by completing requisite
formalities and further refer to circular dated 4.4.1991 instructing expeditious
appointments of MPSC recommended candidates and to speed up the process, wherever,
delays in such appointments have been brought to notice by the Members of Legislative
Assembly/Council.
9. The applicants make a grievance that though MPSC had recommended their
candidature to the government for appointment on 11.7.1988 and though they were
directed to undergo medical examination under communication dated 8.9.1988, yet the
orders were issued to them only on 1.7.1989 i.e. almost after about twelve months.
10. The applicants' grievance is also that on 29.6.1989 i.e. just two days before their
orders of appointment dated 1.7.1989, orders of promotion of in-service candidates from
MDS Class-II cadre had been issued by which en-bloc ten persons were promoted. It has
been alleged that intervening 23 promotions from the date of recommendation of the
applicants to the date of their actual appointments had been calculated at giving
precedence to the promotee candidates over the direct recruits. The promotee candidates
who retired before the applications were filed, have been excluded from being arrayed as
respondents. The applicants purport to allege that long distance in the appointments
had been influenced by the promotee candidates. The applicants contend that not only

the ten candidates referred to above, but respondents No. 4 to 26 have been promoted 
 
 keeping the issue of appointment of the applicants in abeyance.
11. The applicants allege that even the constitution of the Departmental Promotion
Committee [hereinafter referred to as the "DPC"] had been subsequent to the date on
which applicants' names were recommended by MPSC and thus claim that the
departmental candidates' selection is subsequent in point of time. The applicants have
also contended that since the government had requisitioned direct recruits to the MPSC
in 1987 pursuant to which their selection had been made, it has to be presumed that
there were vacancies of direct recruits in MDS Class-I cadre. The applicants purported to
urge the Tribunal to consider the aspect as to why the State Government had remained
inactive and as to how it has issued orders of appointment of the applicants immediately
after the date of promotion of the in-service candidates. Sum and substance is to allege
that the deferred issuance of appointment orders to them has been malafide, with a view
to favour the promotee candidates. The applicants contend that regularization of
promotion of the departmental candidates had not taken place. Placing the departmental
promotee candidates over the direct recruits in the seniority list dated 7.6.1996 is grossly
improper and that though they sought redressal of their grievance regarding said
seniority list under a representation dated 15.1.1999, yet there has been no response.
12. The respondents-applicants claimed that there was no avenue available to those
working in MDS Class I cadre till 1999. It is only in 1999 the government has given
them opportunity of getting Selection Grade in MDS cadre and also promotional avenue
in the form of Additional Chief Executive Officer and thus they have contended that
creation of the cadre of Additional Chief Executive Officer shall have to be deemed to be
a reckoning point for the applicants to ventilate their grievance about seniority as taking

up such issue to judicial forum at other point of time would have generally been an 
 
 academic exercise. The applicants this way justify their approach to the Tribunal

questioning the seniority list dated 7.6.1996 and claimed that soon after declaration of 
 
 policy of the State to provide opportunity of advancement to the candidates in MDS
Class-I, they have agitated for correction in the seniority list and have requested the
Tribunal to appreciate and consider their case favourably. The applicants allege that the
promotee candidates were in excess of their quota.
13. Respondent No. 1 in its affidavit in reply dated 12.1.2001 has denied allegations
of the applicants and has asserted that quota of direct recruits and promotees was and
has been maintained according to the MDS rules. The objections against interim
seniority list received, were considered properly and thereafter seniority list was
finalized. It has been submitted that interim seniority list had been prepared on
2.8.1995 and after inviting and considering objections to the same, on 7.6.1996,
seniority list has been finalized. It has been submitted that MDS Rules, 1973 have been
made effective from July, 1981 and the MPSC had been requisitioned in 1984.
Examination was held in 1985 and 14 and 16 candidates were appointed in 1986 and
1987 respectively through the Commission and as such, the respondent-authorities had
fulfilled the quota of direct recruits. It has been specifically denied that the departmental
candidates had been promoted against the nomination quota. The Rural Development
Department had prepared seniority list according to the relevant rules and ratio of direct
recruits and promotees had been maintained in accordance with the rules. It has been
denied that the seniority list of the candidates of MDS Group-A requires any alteration.
In support of said contention, reliance has been placed by Respondent No. 1 on various
documents annexed to the reply, including MDS Rules, 1973 and amendments thereto
from time to time.

14. 
 
 The applicants had filed rejoinder on 13.2.2001 to the affidavit in reply

submitted by Respondent No.1 and expressed their inability to give definitive figures of 
 
 various posts in MDS Class-I cadre and tried to reason that out on various counts. It has
been contended that since Class-I posts were en-bloc converted into Class-II and some of
the Class-II posts had been up-graded as Class-I posts, referring to that about 200 posts
of Child Development Programme Officer (CDPO) which were earlier Class I had been
converted into Class II. According to them, certain number of posts had been increased
and altogether new posts were created like Assistant Commissioner, Additional Chief
Officer of Zilla Parishad and also submitted that in the absence of exact figures, effective
adjudication of the issue would be difficult. It is further submitted that strength of the
MDS Class-I cadre is about 397 or thereabout throughout the State. Till rejoinder, the
posts of Assistant Commissioner from said cadre had been increased from 6 to 18 and
the posts of Block Development Officer Class-I which were 32 had been increased to 202
and about 150 posts of CDPOs had been abolished by shifting them as Block
Development Officer Class-II with conversion of CDPOs to MDS Class II from Class I
cadre. According to the applicants, there were only 93 direct recruits among 397 posts
which is far too below the requirement of 50 per cent under the quota rule since
1.4.1982 and claimed a backlog of 105 posts of direct recruits. The applicants purport
to dispute the date of application of rules as of 1979. The applicants have also contended
that the objection to seniority list is a different issue altogether and does not have nexus
to the controversy involved in Original Application No. 256 of 2000 and thus questioned
importance being given to the issue of not availing an opportunity to object to the
seniority list. The applicants further went on to submit that though the issues are inter-
mixed, those are, in fact, independent of each other. It has been submitted that
maintenance of quota can be considered independently from seniority. It has been

contended that promotions in favour of the concerned respondents-departmental 
 
 candidates had been temporary and by way of stop gap arrangement and relying upon 
 
 judicial pronouncements of the Apex Court and the Tribunal further contended that
promotions of the departmental candidates are fortuitous and apprehended that their
long tenure would be legitimized. The applicants purport to claim that in their objections
to the seniority list they had relied on Sanjay Thakre's case decided by the Tribunal and
referred to that challenge to said decision of the Tribunal before the Apex Court had
been unsuccessful.
15. An additional affidavit has been filed by Respondents No. 1 to 3 on 7.3.2001 to
the rejoinder of the applicants, objecting to Original Application No. 256 of 2000 on
various grounds, inter alia, that the same is barred by limitation, is misconceived, is not
tenable, is on fancied cause of action, is stale, fixation of seniority and change in postings
cannot be allowed after more than 12 years, etc. It has been contended that the original
application has been filed far beyond expiry of period of one year from accrual of cause of

action as per 
Section 21
 of the Administrative Tribunals Act, 1985 and that too has been
filed without any application for condonation of delay. It has further been submitted

that there is no compliance of requirement under 
section 20
 of said Act, namely, making
an appeal and in the absence of provision of appeal, a representation. According to the
respondents, even though promotions have been given in 1989, no appeals had been
filed then and even if it is considered that the applicants were aggrieved by fixation of
seniority as on 7.6.1996, neither representation nor appeal has been filed within the

91. It cannot be ignored that MDS class I cadre is a creature of MDS Rules, 1973 and
the rules create specific number of MDS Class I cadre posts under sub rule 4 of Rule 3
and Rule 5 provides for recruitment to the same by nomination and promotion and also
provides for interse proportion thereof and mechanism to bring about change in number
of posts is referred to under sub rule 6 of Rule 3.
92. While it is nobody's case that there had occurred change to number of MDS Class I
posts contained in the MDS Rules, 1973, it is also not the case of rival parties that the
State Government by order in official Gazette has altered the number of MDS Class-I
posts.
93. The stand of the State Government in matter that quota of direct recruits being
fulfilled cannot be lightly discarded and carries lot of credibility. Upon perusal of of rule
that MDS Class-l comprised of 106 posts and with induction of applicants' batch of 40 the
quota of direct recruits had been fulfilled. The applicants could not repel this position by
convincingly dealing with the same with facts and figures though they tried to wrangle
over it contending that the posts of project, programme, planning, regional nutrition,
child development officers form part of MDS Class-I cadre and contending that cadre
consists of much larger number. However, it will have to be observed that said contention

is devoid of substance as said posts were never included MDS Class-l cadre by adopting 
 
 the process referred to in sub-rule (6) of Rule 3 of MDS Rules, 1973 nor those were

considered to form part of the same by the State Government at any point of time. Said 
 
 posts cannot be said to acquire that status under prolonged continuance unless and until
the same is recognized and conferred by employing mechanism provided for bringing
about the same as stipulated in the MDS Rules, 1973. Inclusion of said posts in MDS
Class-l cadre is possible only through the mode of notification by the State Government in
the official gazette not otherwise. The State Government has never accepted said posts as
MDS Class-l cadre posts and have in no uncertain terms denied such claims time and
again, repeatedly, in pleadings and on affidavits before the Tribunal and even by
challenging the orders of Tribunal wherein directions are issued to consider those as such
for quota and seniority. It has also to be considered that attributes of permanency of said
posts or acquisition of permanent status by itself would not clothe the posts with the
status of MDS Class-l cadre and would not be of any significance for birth in the said
cadre and does not at all cause conversion to MDS Class-l cadre.
94. Perusal of the judgment and order of the Tribunal would reveal that the directions
as given by the Tribunal are in total conflict with the rules governing the field. The
Tribunal by the impugned order has purported to 're-enact' the rules under the garb of
placing interpretation which, in our considered view, is not permissible in law.
95. The Government had very specifically stated that the ratio of direct recruits had
been as per the quota rules and further that proportion of appointments of direct recruits

has been in excess till 1990 specifically referring to figures of posts available in cadre 
 
 and number of direct recruits in the same. Though applicants have tried to dispute the

same, the situation cannot be ignored that there has been no increase or decrease in 
 
 number of MDS Class-I cadre posts when the applicants were appointed. The applicants
want to consider other posts to form MDS Class-l cadre which under law is not possible,
without following the procedure contained in the MDS Rules, 1973.
96. There has been no declaration about there being any alteration, increasing or
reducing number of MDS class-l cadre posts, as required under sub-rule 6 of Rule 3 of
MDS Rules, 1973. Said MDS Rules of 1973 underwent various amendments from time
to time, without alteration of the number of MDS Class-I cadre posts. The number of
MDS Class-l cadre posts has not been touched by the amendments which have been
placed on record by the authorities. Said position has not been disputed by applicants.
The posts which the Tribunal has referred to as having attributes of permanency appear
to be from pools out side MDS Class-I cadre. It appears that the creation of said posts had
been with a specific purpose for implementation of schemes/programmes/projects under
directions and orders of the Central/State Governments.
97. There had been no amalgamation of said posts with those in the MDS Class-I cadre
at any point of time by following the procedure as prescribed and required under sub-
rule 6 of rule 3 of MDS Rules of 1973. In absence of any such action by the Government
for amendment or alteration to number of posts under the rules by amalgamation, the
directions given by the Tribunal rewriting the rules are grossly ill-conceived. So long as
the procedure for increase or decrease in number of Class-I cadre posts is not followed by
State, such directions by the Tribunal would not be tenable.

98. Government Decision dated 07-03-1996 pressed into service by applicants has little 
 
 efficacy in the present controversy and hardly has any application to the situation. The

Government decision has been issued for application and maintenance of quota system 
 
 where there are no rules, governing recruitments in government services. Perusal of the
same would show that the stipulations thereunder would hold good wherever there are
no provisions for quota system in the rules. Further, it provides for regular revisions and
the conversion of temporary posts over three years into permanent, with the concurrence
of finance department with view to facilitate maintaining proportion of quota. It also
makes clear that the said Government decision would be applicable prospectively from
01-04-1996. In the present matter, no case has even been pleaded about conversion of
posts, into permanent ones, taking place with the concurrence of finance department. It
has also to be taken into account that application of said Government decision to the
posts which the applicants want to be considered to be of MDS Class-I cadre has not been
accepted by the respondent authorities. Having regard to aforesaid, it will have to be
considered that Government Resolution hardly has any significance in present
controversy and that apart the same would not cover the period before
01-04-1996. As such, the directions with reference to the same issued by Tribunal in
respect of period prior to 1996 would not be sustainable. The Tribunal has not dealt with
said aspect of Government Resolution and altogether disregarded that it was operative
99. It appears that without there being concrete material on record the Tribunal has
inferred that there are lot of accounting errors in identifying permanent posts and that
the respondents have proved that there were adequate slots available for direct recruits.
100. The position that clearly emerges is that pursuant to the rules and the position as

stated in the affidavits in reply, the number of posts in MDS Class I cadre were 95 in 
 
 1988-89 comprising 54 permanent and 44 temporarily sanctioned. With the
appointment of batch of 40 persons including the respondents-applicants, in 1990,
position was that 71 posts were occupied and held by direct recruits. In fact, the
authority had categorically submitted with figures indicating as stated by the
respondents, the quota of appointments of the direct recruits had been fulfilled. The
respondents-applicants had in clear terms expressed their inability to furnish
proper/exact figures of the posts available for direct recruits in MDS Class I cadre. They
were not in a position to discard the submission that the posts viz. Project Director
(DRDA), Programme Officer, DPAP, Planning Officer, Regional Nutrition Officers and
Child Development Officers which they have contended to form part of MDS Class I
cadre, were not included in MDS Class I cadre or for that matter, there has been any
government resolution in that respect. The respondents-applicants want that these posts
should be deemed to be included in MDS Class I cadre in the absence of any notification
which, according to them, have attributes of permanent posts pursuant to the order of the
Tribunal dated 22.11.2002
101. In our considered view, the Tribunal has been in error in putting in a long arm,
especially in the absence of any concrete material before it. The authorities which have
been relied on by the respondents-applicants are of little help to them, having regard to
the fact that the situation is occupied and governed by specific rules holding the field

of operation and the respondents-applicants have to abide by the same from 
 
 inception with their appointments. Quota rules and absence of observance of the same

have been much harped about. However, the respondents-applicants have not been able 
 
 to show as to how quota rule has not been followed, especially when they are not in a
position to say that the posts which they want to be part of MDS Class I cadre had ever
been amalgamated with MDS Class-I cadre by a notification under a government gazette
as required by sub-rule 6 of Rule 3 of MDS Rules, 1973. The decision rendered by the
Tribunal is on hypothetical basis, without any concrete material in support thereof, is
based on assumptions and presumptions and surmises and conjectures. In our view, the
Tribunal has grossly misdirected itself in allowing the Original Applications.
102. It is incomprehensible that the Tribunal assumes role of legislature and purports
to legislate which the rules did not intend. There is no room for 'casus omissus' as the
intention under the rules has been clear and unambiguous, to have variable ratio in
appointments of direct recruits viz; 35 to 50 per cent.
103. It is obvious that so long as there is no addition or reduction to MDS Class I posts
referred to under sub rule (4) of Rule 3 of other posts over and above said MDS Class I
cadre posts, such posts would not automatically form part of that cadre. It is apparent
that unless and until the posts which the applicants wanted to form part of MDS cadre
are actually included in that cadre by increasing number of posts of MDS Class I cadre by
following procedure under sub-rule (6), the contention of the applicants would not hold
water and would not be justified. There has been serious and gross error in rendering
decision and issuing directions without reference to sub-rule (6) of Rule 3 and in being
oblivious about the existence of the same. The discussion by the Tribunal, therefore, has

to be considered as strayed one. Perusal of impugned order indicates that the Tribunal 
 
 has practically rewritten the rules. The other considerations which have weighed with 
 
 the Tribunal have little relevance so far as posts in MDS Class I cadre are concerned.
104. Perusal of sub-rule (6) of rule 3 would reveal that the State Government has been
empowered either to increase or decrease the number of posts or to designate or include
more categories of posts or exclude any category of post in the cadre. However, it is
nobody's case that by exercise of such power vested in it, the State Government has, at
any point of time, increased the number of posts in MDS Class-I cadre. It is, thus, clear
that the directions given by the learned Tribunal are totally contrary to the statutory rules.
105. The Tribunal has been absolutely in error in placing an interpretation on the
proviso to rule 5 the way in which it has been placed in the judgment and order on
22.11.2002. The same amounts to virtually rewriting text of the rule, particularly in
absence of such intent reflected, submitted or advanced. Expansion of dispute beyond
the scope of MDS Rules, 1973 is grossly misplaced. Wording in proviso to rule 5 does
not in any way suggest or give allowance to interpretation as has been placed and in the
process, proviso had been re-written by the Tribunal. The proviso to rule 5 of MDS
Rules, 1973 on reading, plainly reveals that intention under the same is to have flexibility
in the appointments to MDS Class-I cadre, taking pragmatic view of the situations those
arise in making appointments. However, at the same time, the range within which
flexibility is available has been specifically provided for. Having regard to this, it appears
that the Tribunal has been influenced by considerations which are extraneous to the
MDS Rules, 1973.
106. Posts which the Tribunal required the Government to consider having attributes

of permanency and to be reckoned for MDS Class-I cadre, is without taking into account 
 
 the provisions of the statutory rules. The Tribunal's directions and orders in such a
scenario would be wholly misconceived.
107. The force of contention of the applicants that the appointments of the petitioners
herein have been by way of stop gap arrangement and have not been regularized is
watered down as it can be borne out from the applicants' pleading that the respondents'
promotion have approval of Departmental Promotion Committee which is the proper
channel. There appears to be no dispute about such assertions of the respondent-
authorities. It would further be required to be taken into consideration that it has
emerged that there is no change in the number of posts in Class I cadre under the MDS
Rules, 1973 and there appears to be no dispute about figure of appointments of direct
recruits in MDS cadre. As such, the appointments of promotees cannot be said to
impinge on the quota of direct recruits in MDS Class I cadre. Having regard to the
position that the quota rule has been followed and proper quota of direct
recruits finds place in the number of posts in MDS Class I cadre according to the rules,
the authorities referred to and relied upon on behalf of the applicants have little role in
the present controversy.
108. When the field is governed and occupied by specific rules, as in present case like
MDS Rules 1973 which have been clear and unambiguous, there had been no room to
place an interpretation on the same than its plain words. The Tribunal as such has erred
in going beyond the spirit and letter of the proviso to clause (a) of sub rule (1) of Rule 5.
109. Though rival arguments have been advanced before us by petitioners so also by

the respondents that the original application was beyond limitation and per contra that it 
 
 is within limitation, we do not find it necessary to go into that aspect of the matter. The
learned Tribunal after hearing the parties has decided the matter on merits. We have
also considered the matter on merits and, as such, it would not be appropriate at this
stage to go into that issue.
110. In our considered view, therefore, the Tribunal has wholly misconceived the
scope of the matter before it had been in error all over. The impugned order cannot be
justified with the aid of material on record. The Tribunal, thus, has erred in issuing
impugned directions to prepare fresh seniority list. Looking at the matter in any way,
the impugned order passed by the Tribunal dated 22-11-2002 and the one dated
28-04-2004 are wholly unsustainable and deserve to be quashed and set aside and as its
incident, the impugned seniority list would not be able to stand.
111. Therefore, the order dated 22-11-2002 of the Tribunal and all other orders
including the orders in contempt petition and in the review applications deserve to be
quashed and set aside.
112. In the result, writ petitions are allowed. The order dated 22.11.2002 passed by
the Maharashtra Administrative Tribunal, Aurangabad Bench, in Original Applications
No. 254 and 256 of 2000 and the subsequent orders dated 28.4.2004 and 21.2.2006 in

Contempt Petition No. 89 of 2003, so also order dated 3.11.2004 in Review Applications 
 
 No. 11 and 12 of 2004, are set aside. Consequently, seniority lists prepared by the

Department of Rural Development and Water Conservation of the State Government 
 
 dated 21.11.2005 in pursuance of the directions under the aforesaid orders of the
Tribunal, is also set aside.
113. Rule made absolute in aforesaid terms without there being any order as to costs.
114. In view disposal of writ petitions, civil applications are also disposed of.
